'''''Rhizomarasmius epidryas''''' ([[synonym (taxonomy)|syn]]. '''''Marasmius epidryas''''' or '''''Mycetinis epidryas''''') is one of a group of mushrooms formerly in the genus ''[[Marasmius]]''.  It grows amongst dwarf shrubs of the genus [[Dryas (plant)|''Dryas'']] in arctic or [[alpine climate|high mountain]] environments.<ref name=Antonín/><ref name=FungaNordica/><ref name=SF/>

==Description==
The species can be described as follows:<ref name=Antonín/><ref name="FungaNordica"/><ref name=Moser/> 
*The cap is brownish yellow and grows to about 1 cm in diameter.
*The gills are white and fairly distant, and broadly attached to the stem. The spore powder is white. 
*The stem can grow to 4 cm tall by up to 2 mm in diameter, being broader at the apex. It is brown above and blackish brown at the base, with a velvety covering of hairs.  
*The smell and taste are not distinctive.
*The spores are roughly ellipsoid or almond-shaped and measure roughly 8.5-10.5 µm x 5-7 µm.

==Naming and related species==
The [[botanical name|species epithet]] is the Ancient Greek prefix "epi-" (ἐπί), meaning "on",<ref name=Liddell/> followed by [[Dryas (plant)|Dryas]], the genus of plants with which it grows.

This species was originally described as ''Marasmius epidryas'' by [[Robert Kühner]] in 1935 in the annals of the [[:w:fr:Société linnéenne de Lyon|Linnaean Society of Lyon]], but the definition was considered invalid due to the lack of a Latin description according to the updated [[International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants|nomenclatural rules]].  In 2009 Anna Ronikier published a correct description ascribing the name to Kühner (that is, giving credit to him) and so the first valid name with author attribution was "''Marasmius epidryas'' Kühner ex A. Ronikier".  Then in 2011 Anna & Macheł Ronikier established that the species belongs in the new genus ''[[Rhizomarasmius]]'' and redefined the current name accordingly.<ref name="Roniker 2011"/><ref name=SF/> 

==Ecology and distribution==
This mushroom is found exclusively in cushions of [[Dryas (plant)|''Dryas'']] plants such as [[Dryas octopetala|''D. octopetala'']] (mountain avens) and [[Dryas integrifolia|''D. integrifolia'']] (entire-leaved avens), growing saprobically on dead leaves and stems. It only occurs in arctic or [[alpine climate|high mountain]] environments.<ref name=Antonín/><ref name="FungaNordica"/>

It is reported from arctic regions of Europe and North America, the [[Rocky Mountains|Rocky]] and [[Altai mountains|Altai]] mountains, and various mountain ranges in Europe.<ref name=Antonín/><ref name=FungaNordica/>
